utterances: Well, one of the things that makes it more insidious is the fact that not only is it using those NSA exploits, but it's able to steal passwords from the machine and spread even if the machine is perfectly secure and patched against all the latest vulnerabilities that those previous ransomware were using.
So this is a huge problem.
We've seen these types of attacks in the past.
This one in particular seems to be hitting organizations in the U.S.
more than the WannaCry attack, which was stopped early on at the time when it was impacting organizations in Europe.
So it's a big problem.
And for an institution that has been hacked and that didn't pay a ransom, what sort of jeopardy are they in?
What might happen to them?
Well, hopefully they have backups to restore their data because unfortunately the encryption in the ransomware is so good that restoring it in any other way is pretty much impossible.
Pretty much impossible.
The security is very good.
And if they don't have a good backup, like the National Health Service it seemed was inadequately backed up...
The data is gone.
It's just gone.
Dmitri Alperovitch, thanks for talking with us.
Thank you.
Mr. Alperovitch is co-founder and chief technology officer of the cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike.
On February 2nd, Republicans in the House of Representatives are scheduled to vote on a permanent replacement for Tom DeLay as majority leader.
Roy Blunt of Missouri wants the job.
He's been majority leader since September, when Mr. DeLay was indicted in Texas and had to step aside.
Mr. Blunt's main opponent is John Boehner of Ohio, who now chairs the Committee on Education and Workforce.
The Blunt and Boehner camps both have been working hard to line up votes.
On Friday, John Shadegg of Arizona got into the race.
He resigned his post as the fifth-ranking Republican, chair of the Republican Policy Committee.
Alan Ota is a senior writer for Congressional Quarterly in Washington.
He joins us from there.
Welcome.
Thank you.
Congressman Blunt and his allies had wanted this vote to be taken sooner.
Does either he or Congressman Boehner seem to have an insurmountable lead at this point?
What about all the speculation that Obama will strike a bargain with Clinton, say, cabinet member, vice president?
Those who know her best say, not a chance.
And Senator Clinton, who has invested so much into becoming not the first lady but the first woman in the White House, says she's going to stay in the race until the nominating convention in August.
Bill Clinton, in his speech in California, also urged Democrats to support a nomination battle right up to the convention.
We are going to win this election, he said, if we just chill out and that everybody have their say.
The comeback kid is a Clinton tradition.
It looks as though, if Senator Clinton does go down, she will go down with all guns blazing.
This is Daniel Schorr.
Voters in the Fifth Congressional District of Massachusetts have a rare opportunity, the chance to fill an open seat.
Democratic Congressman Marty Meehan has resigned to take a job in academia.
Ten candidates are running to succeed Meehan in the September 4th primary.
Among them are the brother of a 9/11 victim and a widow of a presidential candidate.
From member station WBUR in Boston, Fred Thys reports.

As Niki Tsongas goes door to door in the district's largest city, Lowell, an old industrial town that is undergoing a renaissance, it's clear that she benefits from the fact that she is the widow of Paul Tsongas.
Tsongas is still widely respected in the congressional district he represented before being elected to the U.S.
Senate, then running for president in 1992.
He died 10 years ago.
Unidentified Woman #1: Yeah.
Good talking to you.
I'm really going to vote for you.
I loved Paul.
Miss him.
Thank you.
Yeah.
He was remarkable…
Yeah.
He really was.
…politician.
He showed us all what can be done…
Yes.
…in Washington, if you commit to it.
He did.
Yeah.
Tsongas says her top priority is to end the war in Iraq.
She supports creating a timetable for withdrawing U.S.
troops.
If elected, she would become the first Democratic congresswoman for Massachusetts in more than three decades.
But Tsongas is not the only woman in the race.
Also running is Lowell City Councilor Eileen Donoghue.
After a candidate's forum in the Victorian town hall in Ayer with its cathedral ceiling and restored incised beams, Mary Craft Shirley(ph) says her choice is coming down to the two women in the race.
I like Niki Tsongas.
I like her and I like Eileen Donoghue.
So it would be nice if they could win together and both go and serve us together.
I don't know which one I'm going to vote for right now.
The legacy of Paul Tsongas has opened up a wide-ranging network of contributors for Niki Tsongas.
As a result, she's the best-financed candidate in the race.
She's raised more than a million dollars.
Her name gives her another advantage over her Democratic rivals.
They have a hard time catching up to her because few people pay attention to politics in summer and the primary is the day after Labor Day.
Jeffrey Gerson is professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts at Lowell.
Everyone feels it's Niki Tsongas' race to win or lose.
The frontrunner benefits from a shorter campaign season.

Republicans are pinning their hopes on another famous name here - Jim Ogonowski is the brother of John Ogonowski, the pilot of American Airlines Flight 11 who was killed on 9/11 when terrorists crashed his plane into New York's World Trade Center.
After his brother's death, Jim Ogonowski took over the family farm in Dracut, a town where stonewalls lined country lanes.
At 7:30 in the morning, Ogonowski is greasing his hay baler.
In many ways, he's a typical northeastern Republican.
He supports legalized abortion, but wants to cut taxes.
Shocking to know, if you look at these buildings and all the equipment that you see here, the number one cost to produce a bale of hay is taxes.
Ogonowski says he initially opposed the war in Iraq, but believes the U.S.
should stay until the civilian population is secure.
He says if he wins the primary, he does not want President Bush to campaign for him.
Ogonowski's path to the GOP nomination is considered much easier than his chances in the October general election.
Republicans haven't elected one of their own in this district since 1972 when they beat a fellow by the name of John Kerry.
For NPR News, I'm Fred Thys.
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY, I'm Ira Flatow.
Earlier this week, the New York Times reported new CDC data on diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, ADHD, in kids.
And the numbers are startling, with 11 percent of the parents surveyed reporting a diagnosis of ADHD for their school-age kids, higher numbers for some sub-groups of age and gender.
That's a big jump.
Estimates before that had been that ADHD affected somewhere from three to seven percent of children.
So what's behind the surge in numbers?
Is the spike real, or is it just a reporting error?
And what does that increase in diagnoses mean?
Joining us now to talk about it is William Graf, he's a professor of pediatrics and neurology at Yale School of Medicine in New Haven.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Hi Ira, thanks for inviting me.
Were you surprised by these numbers?

Yeah, these numbers are pretty high, and it is surprising, and I think that on one hand they're sort of real because we've seen this change over the last two decades as the rates have slowly gone up, and on the other hand they're inflated a little bit, probably because of the way they were obtained.
I just was curious if there were any other means of conveyance that worked that weren't the actual answer that the - that you were looking for.
So there was - so on social media there was quite a reaction to that moment.
And there was a very small negative reaction - much, much smaller than we expected.
And there was this wonderful, you know, positive reaction.
You know, it was a really beautiful reaction.
The thing that we're most excited about is the idea of a couple of years from now, this show starting to be performed in high schools.
And again, this - you know, normalizing this situation so that it isn't an issue anymore at that level.
That's - that's, I think, the most beautiful gift that, you know, commercial theater can give us (laughter).
